questions.text: A 61 year old man presented to the hospital with shortness of breath, decreased exercise capacity and distended neck veins. The man had a history of severe hypertension currently treated with hydrochlorothiazide and captopril. Despite the treatment, his blood pressure was still 170/110. After physical examination and laboratory tests, a diagnosis of diastolic cardiac failure was made. Which of the following would be a useful drug to add to the patient's therapeutic regimen?
questions.solution:
Beta-blockers are drugs of choice in diastolic heart failure because

  • They slow the heart rate, thus allowing more time for complete ventricular filling.
  • They increase heart relaxation, thus counteracting the stiffness of the ventricular wall.
  • They reduce myocardial oxygen demand.

Congestive heart failure

  • Although β blockers can acutely worsen heart failure, several studies have reported beneficial haemodynamic effects of certain β blockers, namely metoprolol, bisoprolol, nebivolol and carvedilol over long-term in selected patients with dilated cardiomyopathy.
  • The hemodynamic benefit is maintained over long-term and hospitalization/mortality due to worsening cardiac failure, as well as all cause mortality is reduced.
  • The benefits appear to be due to antagonism of ventricular wall stress enhancing, apoptosis promoting and pathological remodelling effects of excess Sympathetic activity (occurring reflexly) in heart failure, as well as due to prevention of sinister arrhythmias.
  • β-blockers lower plasma markers of activation of sympathetic, renin-angiotensin systems and endothelin-1.

Option B, C & D: Inotropic drugs are usually contraindicated in diastolic heart failure because they do not relieve the high end diastolic pressure and may induce arrhythmias.

Key takeaway

Beta-blockers are drugs of choice in diastolic heart failure

[Good to Know]

[Metoprolol]

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page number:164, 566-567

questions.text: An 76 year old elderly hypertensive was brought to his physician for treatment of essential hypertension. He later was treated with hydrochlorothiazide 50 mg daily. Even after a month, his BP was not reduced to the desired level and another antihypertensive was added. After 2 hours of taking the other drug his BP fell precipitously. Which of the following drug is most likely given to him?
questions.solution:
• Captopril lowers BP, but in the short-term, magnitude of response is dependent on the Na+ status and the level of RAS activity.
  • In normotensive Na+ replete individuals, the fall in BP attending initial few doses of ACE inhibitors is modest.
  • Fall in BP is more marked when Na+ has been depleted by dietary restriction or diuretics, because renin level is high.
  • In CHF also, the renin level is raised and antihypertensive doses of captopril initially cause marked fall in BP.
  • A greater fall in BP also occurs in renovascular, accelerated and malignant hypertension.
  • In essential hypertension it has been found that RAS is overactive in 20%, normal in 60% and hypoactive in the rest.

Key takeaway

Hypotensive actions of captopril is more marked when Na+ has been depleted by dietary restriction or diuretics, because renin level is high.

[Must Know]

[Captopril]

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page number:530

questions.text: Which one of the following anti-hypertensive is most likely to be associated with development of reflex tachycardia as an adverse drug reaction?
questions.solution:
• Drugs may cause vasodilation by opening potassium channels, by releasing nitric oxide, by blocking calcium channels or by acting as agonists of dopamine receptors.
  • All vasodilators can lead to reflex tachycardia due to vasodilation and sodium and fluid retention due to compensatory mechanisms; therefore these are best utilized in combination with diuretics and beta blockers.
  • Major adverse effect of vasodilators is tachycardia and headache (due to dilation of cerebral blood vessels).

Hydralazine/Dihydralazine

  • It is a directly acting arteriolar vasodilator with little action on venous capacitance vessels.
  • Hydralazine reduces t.p.r. and causes greater decrease in diastolic than in systolic BP.
  • Reflex compensatory mechanisms are evoked which cause tachycardia, increase in c.o. and renin release → increased aldosterone → Na+ and
    water retention.
  • Hydralazine has a significant hypotensive effect that activates baroreceptors.

Adverse effects are frequent and mainly due to vasodilatation.

  • Facial flushing, conjunctival injection, throbbing headache, dizziness, palpitation, nasal stuffiness, fluid retention, edema, CHF.
  • Angina and MI may be precipitated in patients with coronary artery disease.
  • Postural hypotension is not prominent because of little action on veins.
  • Paresthesias, tremor, muscle cramps, rarely peripheral neuritis.
  • Lupus erythematosus or rheumatoid arthritis like symptoms

Key takeaway:

Major adverse effect of vasodilators is tachycardia and headache (due to dilation of cerebral blood vessels).

[Good to Know]
[Hydralazine]

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page number:612-613

choices.text: Decreases mortality in patients with congestive heart failure with normal sinus rhythm
Increases vagal tone and decreases AV node conduction
Lengthens the action potential and increases the refractoriness of the heart
Useful in the treatment of Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following is the most accurate statement regarding digoxin?
questions.solution:
• Cardiac glycosides increase vagal tone and decrease AV node conduction.

Mechanism of Action in Atrial Fibrillation

  • In atrial fibrillation (AF), the mechanism of action of digitalis is to cause increased refractoriness of AV nodal pathway (due to vagomimetic action).
  • In AF, atrium beats at very high rate (500 beats/minute), and at such high rates the contractions become ineffective.
  • Thus, aim of treatment in atrial fibrillation is to maintain ventricular rate at low levels.
  • Digitalis does so by its vagomimetic effect that decreases AV conduction.
  • Vagomimetic effect is also responsible for bradycardia due to digitalis therapy.
  • It also decreases the AV conduction.

The changes in ECG include

  • Inversion of T wave
  • Increased PR interval
  • Shortening of QT interval
  • Depression of ST segment

Option A: Mortality is not decreased in patients with normal sinus rhythm because of digoxin toxicity.

Option C: The action potential is decreased and the refractoriness of the heart is decreased.

Option D: Digoxin is contraindicated in Wolff-Parkinson- White syndrome.

Key takeaway:

Cardiac glycosides increase vagal tone and decrease AV node conduction.

[Good to Know]
[Digoxin]

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page number. 557

questions.text: A 42 year old woman had history of having Type II diabetes for 20 years. She is noted to have hypertension with BP in the 150/94 mm of hg range. The urinalysis shows mild proteinuria. Which of the following drug would be the best to treat the hypertension in this individual?
questions.solution:
• ACE inhibitors, such as enalapril, have been shown to reduce the progressive loss of renal function that is often seen in diabetic patients.

Angiotensin Converting Enzyme Inhibitors (ACEI)

  • Captopril, enalapril, lisinopril, ramipril, perindopril, trandolapril, fosinopril and moexipril etc are the compounds in this group.
  • All ACEI are prodrugs except captopril and lisinopril.
  • Other drugs like enalapril are converted to its active metabolite (enalaprilat) and thus are slow acting.
  • ACEI are used for the treatment of hypertension, CHF, evolving MI,
    diabetic nephropathy, diabetic retinopathy, non-diabetic renal disease and also in scleroderma crisis.
  • These drugs reduce proteinuria in diabetic as well as non-diabetic renal disease and also prevent the manifestations of scleroderma crisis which are mediated by angiotensin II.
  • ACE inhibitors are effective and first choice drugs in renovascular and resistant hypertension.
  • They are particularly suitable for diabetic hypertensives in whom they reduce cardiovascular complications more than other antihypertensive drugs, probably by improving endothelial function.

Most frequent adverse effect

  • Dry cough.
  • Angioedema
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Rashes, dysguesia (altered taste sensation)
  • acute renal failure (if used in bilateral renal artery stenosis)

Option B: The nonselective beta blocker, propranolol, would worsen the diabetes.

Option C: It can cause hyperglycemia and would worsen the diabetes.

Option D: Not a preferred choice for this case. Mainly used in hypertensive emergency.

Key takeaway

ACE inhibitors are effective and first choice drugs in renovascular and resistant hypertension.

They are particularly suitable for diabetic hypertensives in whom they reduce cardiovascular complications more than other antihypertensive drugs, probably by improving endothelial function.

[Must Know]
[Enalapril]

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page number. 533-534

questions.text: A 34 year old woman brought to medicine department seeking treatment for recently diagnosed variant angina & later started treatment with Isosorbide mononitrate. Which amongst the following action most likely mediate the therapeutic effect of nitrates in the patient's disease?
questions.solution:
• Nitrates dilate large epicardial vessels, thus increasing epicardial blood flow.
  • This action is the most important for the therapeutic effect of these drugs in variant angina, which is characterized by coronary spasm.
  • Mechanism of relief of angina

Variant angina

  • The relaxant effect on larger coronary vessels is the principal action of nitrates benefiting variant angina by counteracting coronary spasm.

Classical angina

  • The primary effect is to reduce cardiac work by action on peripheral vasculature, though increased blood supply to ischaemic area may contribute.

Option A: By causing venous dilation, nitrates can cause a decrease, not an increase, of left ventricular end-diastolic volume.

Option C: Nitrates can cause reflex tachycardia and reflex increase in cardiac contractility, but these are detrimental, not therapeutic, effects in patients with angina.

Option D: Nitrates can decrease diastolic perfusion time (as a consequence of reflex tachycardia), but this is a detrimental effect in patients with angina.

Key Takeaway

Nitrates dilate large epicardial vessels, thus increasing epicardial blood flow. This action is the most important for the therapeutic effect of these drugs in variant angina, which is characterized by coronary spasm.

[Good to Know]
[Nitrates]

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page number:586

questions.text: A 57 year old man suffering from persistent atrial fibrillation started a treatment with digoxin, one tablet daily. Which of the following types of receptors most likely mediated the therapeutic effect of the drug in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Digoxin is still used in persistent atrial fibrillation (although it is no longer a first-line therapy) because it can decrease the atrioventricular conduction, thus decreasing the high ventricular rate.

This is accomplished by a stimulation of vagal activity due to

  • Stimulation of vagal nuclei in the brainstem
  • Sensitization of carotid sinus baroreceptors
  • Facilitation of muscarinic transmission at the cardiac muscle cells.

The receptors involved in vagal activity on the heart are mainly muscarinic.

Mechanism of Action in Atrial Fibrillation

  • In atrial fibrillation (AF), the mechanism of action of digitalis is to cause increased refractoriness of AV nodal pathway (due to vagomimetic action).
  • In AF, atrium beats at very high rate (500 beats/minute), and at such high rates the contractions become ineffective.
  • Thus, aim of treatment in atrial fibrillation is to maintain ventricular rate at low levels.
  • Digitalis does so by its vagomimetic effect that decreases AV conduction.
  • Vagomimetic effect is also responsible for bradycardia due to digitalis therapy.
  • It also decreases the AV conduction.

Key Takeaway

Digoxin is used in persistent atrial because it can decrease the atrioventricular conduction (via vagomimetic actions involving musarinic receptors), thus decreasing the high ventricular rate.

[Must Know]
[Digoxin]

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page number. 561

questions.text: A 45 year old woman came to medicine outpatient department for routine check up and found to have a heart rate of 150 bpm. The woman had a history of atrial flutter for which she had been receiving quinidine for the past 2 weeks following a successful electrical cardioversion. Which of the following actions best explains the mechanism of this adverse effect of quinidine?
questions.solution:
• Quinidine is still sometimes used to maintain the normal sinus rhythm after cardioversion, but it can cause paradoxical tachycardia, due to its anti-muscarinic action on the heart, which increases atrioventricular conduction.

Quinidine

  • It is the dextro isomer of the antimalarial alkaloid quinine found in cinchona bark.
  • In addition to Na+ channel blockade, quinidine has cardiac antivagal action which augments prolongation of atrial effective refractory period (ERP).
  • A-V node ERP is increased by direct action of quinidine, but decreased by its antivagal action; overall effect is inconsistent.
  • Quinidine depresses myocardial contractility; failure may be precipitated in damaged hearts.

Option B: Quinidine blocks, not activates, α 1 receptors, thus causing peripheral vasodilation.

Option C: By causing vasodilation, quinidine actually decreases the stimulation of arterial baroreceptors.

Option D: Quinidine can block potassium channels.

Key Takeaway

Quinidine is used to maintain the normal sinus rhythm after cardioversion, but it can cause paradoxical tachycardia, due to its anti-muscarinic action on the heart, which increases atrioventricular conduction.

[Good to Know]
[Quinidine]

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page number:573

questions.text: A 67 year old male patient known case of essential hypertension presented to medicine department with renal insufficiency with very low urine output, pedal edema, headache and on examination his BP was 160/90 mmhg. Which of the following anti-hypertensive can be administered to him?
questions.solution:
• Hydrochlorothiazide (HCZ) and chlorthalidone are the diuretic of choice for uncomplicated hypertension; have similar efficacy and are dose to dose equivalent.
  • Chlorthalidone is longer acting (~ 48 hours) than HCZ (< 24 hours) and may have better round-the-clock action; favoured by the NICE guidelines.
  • Indapamide is also mainly used as antihypertensive, and is equally effective.

Desirable properties of thiazide diuretics as antihypertensives are

  • Once a day dosing and flat dose-response curve permitting simple standardized regimens.
  • No fluid retention, no tolerance.
  • Low incidence of postural hypotension and relative freedom from side effects, especially CNS, compared to sympatholytics.
  • More effective in elderly patients and in those with isolated systolic hypertension (ISH).
  • Thiazides decrease Ca2+ excretion; may lower risk of osteoporosis in older women.
  • Low cost.

Key Takeaway

Hydrochlorothiazide (HCZ) and chlorthalidone are the diuretic of choice for uncomplicated hypertension

[Must Know]
[Chlorthalidone]

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page number:605

questions.text: A 45 year old man has been diagnosed of having essential hypertension. A thiazide diuretic agent had been prescribed with continued elevated blood pressure. The inclusion of Spironolactone to the thiazide diuretic is done to achieve which of the following?
questions.solution:
Spironolactone is a "potassium-sparing" diuretic that reduces K+ excretion in the collecting duct. It diminishes the K+ -wasting effects of thiazide diuretics.

Aldosterone antagonists

  • Spironolactone and eplerenone themselves lower BP slightly.
  • Used in conjunction with a thiazide diuretic they prevent K+ loss and augment the antihypertensive action.
  • Spironolactone has hormonal side effects (gynaecomastia, impotence, menstrual irregularities).

Hypokalaemia

  • This is the most significant Problem
  • Degree of hypokalaemia appears to be related to the duration of action of the diuretic; longer acting drugs cause more K+ loss.
  • The usual manifestations are weakness, fatigue, muscle cramps; cardiac arrhythmias are the serious complications.

Hypokalaemia can be prevented and treated by:

(a) High dietary K+ intake or

(b) Supplements of KCl (24-72 mEq/day) or

(c) Concurrent use of K+ sparing diuretics

Key Takeaway

Spironolactone is a "potassium-sparing" diuretic that reduces K+ excretion in the collecting duct. It diminishes the K+ -wasting effects of thiazide diuretics while augmenting the effects of the same.

[Must Know]
[Spironolactone]

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page number. 607

questions.text: A 56 year old male patient came to medicine department seeking treatment for hypercholesterolemia. He was counselled regarding lifestyle and dietary changes and later the patient was started on atorvastatin. During his treatment with atorvastatin, which of the following parameter is important to monitor routinely?
questions.solution:
Rise in serum transaminase can occur during statin therapy hence monitoring of liver function is recommended.

Adverse drug reactions of statins

  • Gastrointestinal complaints
  • Headache
  • Rashes and sleep disturbances are
  • Rise in serum transaminase (Monitoring of liver function is recommended)

Muscle aches are the commonest (10%) side effect. Rise in creatine phosphokinase (CPK) levels occurs infrequently.

Myopathy & rhabdomyolysis is the only serious reaction (rare)

Myopathy and liver injury is more common when nicotinic acid/gemfibrozil or CYP3A4 inhibitor-ketoconazole/ grape fruit juice/ erythromycin/ cyclosporine/HIV protease inhibitor is given concurrently.

Key Takeaway

Rise in serum transaminase (liver enzymes) can occur during statin therapy hence monitoring of liver function is recommended.

[Must Know]
[Atorvastatin]

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page number. 686

questions.text: A 55 year old man complained to his physician blood in his stools and hematuria. Two weeks earlier, the man had started a treatment with warfarin for recurrent deep vein thrombosis. Vital signs were blood pressure 90/60 mm Hg, heart rate 110 bpm. An appropriate therapy was started. Which of the following drugs was most likely administered intravenously to the patient for warfarin overdose?
questions.solution:
• The symptoms of the patient strongly suggest a hemorrhagic complication of warfarin therapy.
  • The standard treatment of warfarin overdose would be vitamin K, but the patient is hypotensive, suggesting that bleeding is life- threatening.
  • In this case, the act ion of vitamin K is too slow to be useful (onset is delayed for 6 hours and is complete by 24 hours).
  • Fresh frozen plasma (which contains prothrombin and factors VII, IX, and X) or activated clotting factors should be administered in case of severe acute bleeding due to anticoagulant therapy.

Adverse effects of warfarin

  • Bleeding as a result of extension of the desired pharmacological action is the most important problem causing ecchymosis, epistaxis, hematuria, bleeding in the g.i.t.
  • Intracranial or other internal haemorrhages may even be fatal.
  • Bleeding is more likely if therapy is not properly monitored, or when the International normalized ratio (INR) exceeds 4, or interacting drugs/contraindications are present.

Treatment

Withhold the anticoagulant.

  • Give fresh blood transfusion; this supplies readymade clotting factors and replenishes lost blood. Alternatively fresh frozen plasma may be used as a source of clotting factors.
  • Give vit K1 which is the specific antidote, but it takes 6-24 hours for the clotting factors to be resynthesized and released in the blood after vit K administration.

Key Takeaway

Bleeding is the most common adverse effect of all anticoagulants.

If a patient develops bleeding due to overdose of warfarin, four factor concentrate or fresh frozen plasma (to supply clotting factors) is the treatment of choice but specific antidote is vitamin K1 (but the action will be delayed).

[Good to Know]
[Fresh frozen plasma]

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page number. 669

questions.text: A 56 year old woman underwent hip replacement procedure. Later she was discharged from the hospital with an appropriate post-discharge therapy that included daily subcutaneous injection of regular heparin for prevention of deep venous thrombosis due to prolonged immobilization. Which of the following laboratory examinations should be performed frequently during the heparin treatment in this patient to avoid its complications?
questions.solution:
• High-molecular-weight heparin (HMWH) causes transient thrombocytopenia in up to 15% of patients and severe thrombocytopenia (which is antibody-mediated) in up to 5% of patients.
  • Because heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) is a serious adverse effect of heparin, a platelet count should be performed weekly during heparin treatment.
  • Any thrombocytopenia appearing during treatment should be considered suspicious for HIT.

Key Takeaway

Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) is a serious adverse effect of heparin, a platelet count should be performed weekly during heparin treatment.

[Good to Know]
[Heparin]

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page number:665

questions.text: A 49 year old woman admitted to the intensive coronary care unit because of an acute myocardial infarction received an appropriate multidrug therapy. On the following day she complained of an abrupt onset headache, followed shortly by vomiting and loss of consciousness. A computed tomography scan of the brain confirmed the diagnosis of stroke due to cerebral hemorrhage. Which of the following drugs most likely contributed to the appearance of the patient's stoke?
questions.solution:
• The standard therapy of myocardial infarction (MI) includes an intravenous thrombolytic drug (alteplase, reteplase, etc.), which is most effective in the first few hours after onset.
  • Bleeding (most common in cerebral vessels) is the most frequent adverse effect of these drugs.

Alteplase

  • Recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (rt-PA)
  • It catalyses the cleavage of endogenous plasminogen to generate plasmin, and is moderately specific for fibrin bound plasminogen, so that circulating fibrinogen is lowered only by ~ 50%.
  • It is rapidly cleared by liver and inactivated by plasminogen Activator inhibitor-1 (PAI-1).
  • The plasma t½ is 4-8 min. Because of the short t½, it needs to be given by slow i.v. infusion and often requires heparin coadministration.
  • Aspirin is also routinely given after establishing reperfusion.
  • Risk of bleeding (0.5-5%) is the most important concern.
  • Alteplase is nonantigenic, but nausea, mild hypotension and fever may occur.
  • It is expensive.

Option A: Aspirin, if not contraindicated, is given at presentation and daily indefinitely thereafter. Its anti-platelet effect reduces short and long-term mortality. Bleeding, however, is not as common as with thrombolytic drugs.

Option B: Beta-blockers, if not contraindicated, are given within the first few hours after onset because they reduce recurrence rate and mortality. Bleeding is not an adverse effect of this drug class.

Option C: Nitroglycerin is recommended for the first 24 to 48 hours in patients with MI and heart failure or hypertension.

Key Takeaway

Bleeding (most common in cerebral vessels) is the most frequent adverse effect of these drugs which is because of the dissolution of already formed clot.

[Good to Know]
[Alteplase]

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page number:674

questions.text: A 56 year old man admitted to the hospital with a myocardial infarction underwent a percutaneous coronary angioplasty for the revascularization of his left coronary. Which of the following drugs was most likely given intravenously during the procedure?
questions.solution:
Various anticoagulation regimens are always performed before, during, and after angioplasty to reduce the incidence of thrombosis.

Heparin and abciximab are the two drugs given intravenously for this purpose.

Acute coronary syndromes (ACSs)

  • These comprise of a range of acute cardiac ischaemic states from
  • Unstable angina (UA)
  • Non-ST elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI)
  • ST elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI)
  • The coronary obstruction in UA and NSTEMI is partial, while that in STEMI is total.
  • UA and NSTEMI are differentiated on the basis of absence or presence of laboratory markers of cardiac myocyte necrosis (myoglobin, CK-MB, troponin I, etc.).
  • Soluble aspirin (325 mg oral) and a LMW heparin (s.c.) are given at presentation to all patients with ACS.

STEMI

  • Primary PCI with or without stent placement is the procedure of choice for all STEMI as well as high risk NSTEMI patients who present within 12 hours.
  • Prasugrel or ticagrelor + aspirin is the antiplatelet regimen most commonly selected for patients who are to undergo PCI.
  • The GPIIb/IIIa antagonists are the most powerful antiplatelet drugs.
  • Abciximab/eptifibatide/tirofiban infused i.v. along with oral aspirin and s.c. heparin markedly reduce incidence of restenosis and subsequent MI after coronary angioplasty.
  • The GPIIb/IIIa antagonists are infused for a maximum of 72 hours.

Option A & B: Warfarin and clopidogrel both are given orally.

Option C: Recombinant factor VIIa is given intravenously for treatment of haemophilic patients.

Key Takeaway

Heparin and abciximab are the two drugs given intravenously for percutaneous coronary angioplasty procedure

[Good to Know]
[Abciximab]

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page number. 680
